description: The problem detail segment contains the data necessary to add, update, correct, and delete the problems of a given individual.

fields.name: Action Code
fields.description: This field contains the intent of the message. Refer to HL7 table 0287 - Problem/goal action code for valid values.

fields.name: Action Date/Time
fields.description: This field contains the date/time that the operation represented by the action code was performed.

fields.name: Degree of precision
fields.description: Degree of precision

fields.name: Problem ID
fields.description: This field identifies the problem. This is the identifier from an institutions master list of problems.

fields.name: Identifier
fields.description: Sequence of characters (the code) that uniquely identifies the item being referenced by the <text>. Different coding schemes will have different elements here.

fields.name: Text
fields.description: Name or description of the item in question. E.g., myocardial infarction or X-ray impression. Its data type is string (ST).

fields.name: Name Of Coding System
fields.description:
Each coding system is assigned a unique identifier. This component will serve to identify the coding scheme being used in the identifier component. The combination of the identifier and name of coding system components will be a unique code for a data item. Each system has a unique identifier.

Refer to User-defined table 0396 Coding Systems for valid values. When an HL7 table is used for a CE data type, the name of coding system component is defined as HL7nnnn where nnnn is the HL7 table number.

fields.name: Alternate Identifier
fields.description: These three components are defined analogously to the above for the alternate or local coding system.  If the alternate text component is absent, and the alternate identifier is present, the alternate text will be taken to be the same as the text component.  If the alternate coding system component is absent, it will be taken to mean the locally-defined system.

fields.name: Alternate Text
fields.description: These three components are defined analogously to the above for the alternate or local coding system.  If the alternate text component is absent, and the alternate identifier is present, the alternate text will be taken to be the same as the text component.  If the alternate coding system component is absent, it will be taken to mean the locally-defined system.

fields.name: Name Of Alternate Coding System
fields.description:
These three components are defined analogously to the above for the alternate or local coding system.  If the alternate text component is absent, and the alternate identifier is present, the alternate text will be taken to be the same as the text component.  If the alternate coding system component is absent, it will be taken to mean the locally-defined system.

Refer to User-defined table 0396 Coding Systems for valid values. When an HL7 table is used for a CE data type, the name of coding system component is defined as HL7nnnn where nnnn is the HL7 table number.

fields.name: Problem Instance ID
fields.description: This field contains the identifier assigned by an initiating system to an instance of a problem.

fields.name: Entity Identifier
fields.description: The first component, <entity identifier>, is usually defined to be unique within the series of identifiers created by the <assigning authority>, defined by a hierarchic designator, represented by components 2 through 4. (See Section 2.9.21, HD - hierarchic designator.)

fields.name: Namespace Id
fields.description: User-defined Table 0300 - Namespace ID is used as the HL7 identifier for the user-defined table of values for this component

fields.name: Universal Id
fields.description: <universal ID> (UID), is a string formatted according to the scheme defined by the third component, <universal ID type> (UID type).  The UID is intended to be unique over time within the UID type.  It is rigorously defined.  Each UID must belong to one of the specifically enumerated schemes for constructing UIDs (defined by the UID type).  The UID (second component) must follow the syntactic rules of the particular universal identifier scheme (defined by the third component).  Note that these syntactic rules are not defined within HL7 but are defined by the rules of the particular universal identifier scheme (defined by the third component).

fields.name: Universal Id Type
fields.description: This component governs the interpretation of the second component of the HD.  If the third component is a known UID refer to HL7 Table 0301 - Universal ID type for valid values, then the second component is a universal ID of that type

fields.name: Episode of Care ID
fields.description: This field uniquely identifies the episode of care to which this problem applies. (See note under Ongoing issues.)

fields.name: Entity Identifier
fields.description: The first component, <entity identifier>, is usually defined to be unique within the series of identifiers created by the <assigning authority>, defined by a hierarchic designator, represented by components 2 through 4. (See Section 2.9.21, HD - hierarchic designator.)

fields.name: Namespace Id
fields.description: User-defined Table 0300 - Namespace ID is used as the HL7 identifier for the user-defined table of values for this component

fields.name: Universal Id
fields.description: <universal ID> (UID), is a string formatted according to the scheme defined by the third component, <universal ID type> (UID type).  The UID is intended to be unique over time within the UID type.  It is rigorously defined.  Each UID must belong to one of the specifically enumerated schemes for constructing UIDs (defined by the UID type).  The UID (second component) must follow the syntactic rules of the particular universal identifier scheme (defined by the third component).  Note that these syntactic rules are not defined within HL7 but are defined by the rules of the particular universal identifier scheme (defined by the third component).

fields.name: Universal Id Type
fields.description: This component governs the interpretation of the second component of the HD.  If the third component is a known UID refer to HL7 Table 0301 - Universal ID type for valid values, then the second component is a universal ID of that type

fields.name: Problem List Priority
fields.description: This field prioritizes this problem on a list that is maintained for the individual.

fields.name: Problem Established Date/Time
fields.description: This field contains the date/time when the corresponding problem was initially identified by the caregiver.

fields.name: Degree of precision
fields.description: Degree of precision

fields.name: Anticipated Problem Resolution Date/Time
fields.description: This field contains the estimated date/time for resolving the stated problem.

fields.name: Degree of precision
fields.description: Degree of precision

fields.name: Actual Problem Resolution Date/Time
fields.description: This field contains the date/time that the problem was actually resolved.

fields.name: Degree of precision
fields.description: Degree of precision

fields.name: Problem Classification
fields.description: This field indicates the kind of problem. This field can be used to categorize problems so that they may be managed and viewed independently within different applications (e.g., admission, final, post-operative, pre-operative, outpatient, discharge, etc.).

fields.name: Identifier
fields.description: Sequence of characters (the code) that uniquely identifies the item being referenced by the <text>. Different coding schemes will have different elements here.

fields.name: Text
fields.description: Name or description of the item in question. E.g., myocardial infarction or X-ray impression. Its data type is string (ST).

fields.name: Name Of Coding System
fields.description:
Each coding system is assigned a unique identifier. This component will serve to identify the coding scheme being used in the identifier component. The combination of the identifier and name of coding system components will be a unique code for a data item. Each system has a unique identifier.

Refer to User-defined table 0396 Coding Systems for valid values. When an HL7 table is used for a CE data type, the name of coding system component is defined as HL7nnnn where nnnn is the HL7 table number.

fields.name: Alternate Identifier
fields.description: These three components are defined analogously to the above for the alternate or local coding system.  If the alternate text component is absent, and the alternate identifier is present, the alternate text will be taken to be the same as the text component.  If the alternate coding system component is absent, it will be taken to mean the locally-defined system.

fields.name: Alternate Text

fields.name: Problem Management Discipline
fields.description: This field indicates the category of caregiver with responsibility for managing this specific problem (e.g., care team, nursing, medicine, respiratory therapy, occupational therapy, dietary etc.). This is a repeating field to allow identification of all disciplines who may have the responsibility for this problem.

fields.name: Problem Persistence
fields.description: This field contains the perseverance of a problem (e.g., acute, chronic, etc.).

fields.description: This field contains the verification status of a problem (e.g., confirmed, differential, provisional, rule-out, etc.).

fields.name: Problem Life Cycle Status
fields.description: This field contains the current status of the problem at this particular date/time (e.g., active, active-improving, active-stable, active-worsening, inactive, resolved, etc.).

fields.name: Problem Life Cycle Status Date/Time
fields.description: This field indicates the effective date/time of the current problem life cycle status.

fields.name: Degree of precision
fields.description: Degree of precision

fields.name: Problem Date of Onset
fields.description: This field contains the date/time when the problem began.

fields.name: Degree of precision
fields.description: Degree of precision

fields.name: Problem Onset Text
fields.description: This field allows for a textual representation of the time when the problem began.

fields.name: Problem Ranking
fields.description: This field contains a user-defined prioritization of a problem (e.g., numeric ranking, or the use of words such as primary, secondary, etc.).

fields.name: Certainty of Problem
fields.description: This field contains a qualitative representation of the certainty of a problem (e.g., HI - high, LO - low, ME - medium, etc.).

fields.name: Probability of Problem
fields.description: This field contains a quantitative or numeric representation of the certainty that the problem exists for this patient. This field has a valid range of 0 to 1. For example, a healthcare provider may be 75% (.75) sure that the problem has been correctly identified.

fields.name: Individual Awareness of Problem
fields.description: This field contains the individuals comprehension of the problem (e.g., full, marginal, partial, etc.).

fields.name: Family/Significant Other Awareness of Problem/Prognosis
fields.description: This field indicates the individuals family or significant others comprehension of the actual problem/prognosis.

fields.name: Security/Sensitivity

fields.name: Name Of Alternate Coding System
fields.description:
These three components are defined analogously to the above for the alternate or local coding system.  If the alternate text component is absent, and the alternate identifier is present, the alternate text will be taken to be the same as the text component.  If the alternate coding system component is absent, it will be taken to mean the locally-defined system.

Refer to User-defined table 0396 Coding Systems for valid values. When an HL7 table is used for a CE data type, the name of coding system component is defined as HL7nnnn where nnnn is the HL7 table number.
